Executive Summary

Hexion Inc.

Deer Park, Texas

(EPA ID: 1000 0017 5614)



The Hexion Inc. facility in Deer Park, TX, referred to as Hexion, is a manufacturing facility owned by Hexion Inc. The facility is located on Highway 225 in Deer Park, Texas. Hexion sells resins & its precursors to other chemical companies that transform them into thousands of consumer products ranging from plastics and coatings to electronics and wind energy. About 150 full-time employees work at the site.



INTRODUCTION AND POLICIES

Hexion is committed to the continuous improvement of chemical safety management. Hexion maintains Environmental, Health, and Safety (EHS) management systems to ensure the safe operation of its facilities is safe for our workers, the public, and environment. As part of this commitment, Hexion invests resources in various areas of accident prevention, such as:



* Safety in process design;

* Safe operating policies and procedures;

* A comprehensive mechanical integrity program;

* Management of process changes;

* Training;

* Incident investigation and auditing; and

* Emergency response participation.



Hexion works closely with our Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC) and Community Advisory Council (CAC).  Hexion is also committed to the principles outlined under the American Chemical Council's Responsible Care program.  



This document provides an overview of the risk management activities at Hexion, including:



* A description of the facility and substances regulated by the EPA RMP rule (68.155(b))   

* An overview of the Prevention Program to prevent accidental chemical releases (68.155(a) & (c))

* A five-year history of accidental releases of chemicals regulated by EPA's RMP rule (68.155(d))

* An overview of the emergency response program (68.155(e))

* Planned changes to improve safety. (68.155(f))



FACILITY DESCRIPTION AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES

The Hexion Deer Park facility has processes with regulated substances in sufficient quant

ities to be covered under the Risk Management Program (RMP) regulation. The facility is classified as Program Level 3 under the RMP regulation since the site is also required to comply with Occupational Safety and Health Administration's (OSHA) 1910.119 Process Safety Management regulations. The RMP regulated substances stored or processed at this facility include methyl mercaptan, epichlorohydrin and pentane.  



ACCIDENT PREVENTION PROGRAM

Hexion's committed and engaged leaders and associates strive to create a safe environment for ourselves and the communities.  Part of our program involves identifying and taking steps to avoid potential accidental chemical releases. This is accomplished through Process Hazard Analyses and periodic review of policies and procedures. Additionally, the site has various safety features to detect, contain and control, and mitigate the consequences of a release that include:



1. Release detection

   Process alarms

   Operator surveillance

   Portable hydrocarbon monitoring equipment 



2. Release containment and control

   Relief systems designed to prevent equipment over-pressurization (i.e. relief valves and flare)

   Dikes to contain liquid releases

   Automatic control valves to allow rapid isolation of the process



3. Release Mitigation

   Area firewater monitors

   Mobile emergency response equipment

   Trained emergency response personnel



FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

There have been no incidents that require inclusion in the five-year accident history as there were no accidental releases from covered processes that resulted in deaths, injuries, or significant property damage on site, or known offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage.





EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

The overall emergency response program for the Hexion facility is coordinated with the Shell Deer Park Chemical Plant and Shell Deer Park Refining Company through a service agreement with

Shell.  Hexion also works closely with the City of Deer Park's Department of Emergency Services and Harris County's Office of Homeland Security & Emergency Management (OHSEM).  



This coordination includes periodic meetings with or communications to local emergency response officials, local government officials, community members, and industry representatives. Shell and Hexion maintain trained and fully equipped firefighting, HAZMAT, and medical/rescue teams capable of managing a broad range of emergency incidents. 



Hexion also maintains 24 hour communications capability with relevant public agencies, as well as area emergency response organizations (i.e. local fire department, local pollution control agencies, federal agencies, etc.).  Hexion Environmental, Health and Safety personnel are trained to make required notifications to the public agencies as well as to the public via the CAER phone line and emails to the Deer Park Community Advisory Council in the event of a release.



Hexion (through Shell) maintains a written emergency response program designed to protect workers, public safety, and the environment. This program consists of policies and procedures for responding to releases, including actions to be taken in the event of a fire, explosion, or chemical release. These procedures address all aspects of emergency response, including first aid and medical treatment, evacuation, and personnel accountability plans. In addition, there are procedures that address maintenance, inspection, testing, and use of emergency response equipment. Employees receive training in these procedures as necessary to perform their specific response duties. 



The emergency response program is updated as needed to address changes to Hexion processes. The Management of Change process is used to trigger updates to the emergency response plan, including notification and training of personnel affected by the change. 



PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY



Hexion implemented a p

roject that significantly modifies the potential footprint of a methyl mercaptan release from the site.  Historically, the site purchased methyl mercaptan as a raw material.  Due to the toxic nature of methyl mercaptan, Hexion invested in facilities to import an alternate raw material that dissociates into methyl mercaptan and other components on an as needed basis.  This resulted in no on-site storage of methyl mercaptan.  The alternative release scenario represented in the current RMP is from the potential in process losses of the generated methyl mercaptan.



Diligent compliance with our RMP Prevention Program forms the framework on which we will continue to improve the level of safety at the facility. Some of the key components of the safety improvements we expect to achieve are as follows:



1.  The Management of Change provisions ensure that we consider the potential safety and health impacts of any change we make to process chemicals, technology, equipment or procedures.



2.  The Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) provisions serve as a tool to ensure continual evaluation of potential hazards, thereby leading to continual improvements in our safety standards.  PHAs are revalidated at least every 5-years by a team of process operators and unit engineers.



3.  Following a maintenance turnaround or change implementation, Pre-Start-Up Safety Reviews are conducted to ensure that the process is safe to operate, procedures are in place and affected personnel are adequately trained to operate or maintain the process.



4.  The Mechanical Integrity provisions ensure that process equipment and instrumentation are designed, constructed, installed and maintained to minimize the risk of hazardous releases, thereby serving as an integral part of our safety program.



5.  Technical documents are maintained regarding the physical properties of hazardous substances handled at the plant, operating parameters and the design basis for the plant equipment.



6.  Operating Proc

edures have been developed for each process area.  Operating Procedures are reviewed by unit operators, supervisors and engineers for accuracy. The procedures include steps for safe operation during all phases of operation.



7.  Associate training includes both initial and refresher training that covers (1) a general overview of the process, (2) safety, health, and environmental topics, (3) process-specific training on the properties and hazards of the substances in the process and (4) job-specific requirements.



8.  The site uses contractors to supplement its workforce during normal activity as well as turnarounds.  To ensure contractors are trained in the site procedures, Hexion works with the Houston Area Safety Council to develop and administer general as well as site specific training.  Meetings are regularly conducted between Hexion and Contractor Supervisors to share best-practices and learnings from industry related accidents.



9.  Hexion investigates incidents, including near misses that could reasonably have resulted in a serious injury to personnel, the public, or could have caused damage to the environment so that similar incidents can be prevented in the future.  The facility has a formal program in place for reporting incidents, conducting incident investigations, report generation, and tracking of actions resulting from incident investigations.



10.  Hexion has an active plant safety committee that works to improve the health, safety, environmental and security of the facility.  The site also has a program for soliciting health, safety, environmental and security suggestions from plant employees.



11.  An ongoing dialogue with Shell Deer Park and the Deer Park Local Emergency Planning Committee will ensure a constant state of readiness to respond to any potential emergencies, as well as a means to implement improvements as the need develops. In this way, we shall bolster our strong commitment to the safety of our workers and the community.
12.  Internal and third party compliance audits are used to maintain and increase our level of safety protection.
